item.title: Update actions and agent cycle documentation
item.description:
Update actions and agent cycle description within the knowledge base.

The agent cycle images allows you to use a mouse over effect to highlight elements. The action list links to the source code documentation. We will append the description of the actions soon.

item.title: Tutorial and knowledge base working in progress
item.description:
Update the knowledge base and tutorials and add an example repository with source codes and generated jar files also:

  • We reduce the tutorials, so that each tutorial contains only one description with sources. For each tutorial we create a full working example and explain it.
  • On the knowledge base we put a schematic illustration of our agent cycle and compare it with the original Jason cycle.

Tutorials and knowledge base are heavily under developing, because we would like to use LightJason also in teaching

item.title: Add emergency video
item.description:
Our first benchmarking video (which is also inserted into our technical report). The video present a performance test of our framework with 15.000 agents on an emergency scenarion.

The video is running in realtime on a single computer (iMac with 2,9 GHz Intel Core i5, 16 GB RAM and OSX El Captain 10.11.6).

https://vimeo.com/lightjason/emergencyscenario

item.title: Update publication
item.description: We have updated the our publication list and the PDF files for downloading.

item.title: Mobile website
item.description: We have created a mobile version of our website for any mobile devices, but we need to optimize the website for caching.

item.title: Tutorial Update
item.description:
We update the tutorials with a short introduction in efficient beliefbases and communication

The LightJason achitecture allows you to create on-demand beliefbases (which uses a lazy loading) structure. The beliefs within the beliefbase are generated during the agent gets access to the literal. This pattern is very fast and efficient.

The communication of LightJason does not define any build-in agent communication, so for each scenario you need to create your own communication structure. within the tutorial we show you a baseline example to implement communication.

item.title: EUMAS 2016 Slides
item.description: Our slides of our EUMAS 2016 talk, a 15min tutorial to create a full working AgentSpeak(L++) example from scratch.

item.title: REST-API
item.description:
We added a REST-API to control the agent execution structure and behaviour.

The API is written with Jersey and can be included into existing Servlet structures. The component is written as a single add-on for our AgentSpeak(L++) agents and is located in its own repository.

item.title: EUMAS 2016
item.description:
We will join the EUMAS 2016 conference and present our current work. Right now we are within the testing-phase of LightJason’s AgentSpeak(L++). Right now there exist some examples for various domains and applications:

  • Towers of Hanoi ASL and Java class
  • Pokemon-Scenario currently under development
  • Asimov our new research project
  • A full documentation on the website is also still under construction (hope for finishing at the end of Jan 2017)

item.title: Add Railroad / Syntax Diagrams
item.description:
For our AgentSpeak(L++) language defintion, we have created railroad / syntax diagrams based on the EBNF grammar definition.

There are two main diagram types. The diagram are interactive so the grammar rules can be swapped and each element within a rule is clickable and referenced its own definition. The grammar files will be generated automatically based on the current source code definition

  • Agent
  • PlanBundle

item.title: Project is start-up
item.description:
We have created the main website of the project, registered the domain lightjason.org and right now trying to create the first full Maven package.

We are working on a first example similar to the Gold Miners scenario (see JaCaMo) but with OpenGL support with the Java LibGDX library. We will be working on the project and the website continuously.

LightJason is a concurrent BDI multi-agent framework for creating a multi-agent systems with Java. A multi-agent system is part of the research of artificial intelligence. We try to create a framework which allows to add AI algorithms to an existing software-architecture. The framework combines classical artificial intelligence with optimization and fuzzy-logical concepts on a high-scalable concurrency architecture.

The project is inspired by AgentSpeak(L) and Jason, but designed and implemented from scratch. LightJason is fine-tuned to concurrent plan execution suitable for distributed frameworks and aims at efficient and scalable integration with existing platforms. To design agents, this framework uses AgentSpeak(L++), a modular extension of AgentSpeak(L), including new features, e.g.

  • lambda-expression
  • multi-plan / -rule definition
  • explicit repair-action
  • multi-variable assignments
  • parallel execution and thread-safe variables

We are working on the theoretical background and developing the whole system with current software development technologies.

One of our main desires is to publish a full useable framework which can be used in productive systems and is understandable also for non-computer scientists. We try to close the gap between modelling aspects, performance and scalability and human-understandable clean written source code.

Feedback and User Contribution

We welcome any constructive feedback. If you think there is anything missing or wish to contribute to our documentation feel free to contact us.

You can

  • send us pull requests for contributing to our repositories with corrections and further input (preferably)
  • create an issue or
  • write us an email.

item.title: About
item.description:
This project arises during our PhD time, because our research deals with multi-agent systems. Our research projects consider traffic and crowd simulation, but we try to simulate complex manner of human behaviour.

Malte’s research depends on complex overtaking manoeuvre and norm usage with the on a high abstraction level. The research contains a more application-based structure, but it is a great and helpful work, in which way a multi-agent system can be used in complex simulation scenarios.

Philipp’s focus of research is the high scalability of such complex simulation systems with data mining / big data and software developing aspects. His thesis mainly contains algorithms, data structure, software developing and formal structure. The applied software building process is inspired by Scrum and Continuous Integration to get a long-live, robust software architecture.

Based on these perspectives, we can motivate our work. Our work is inspired by Jason, a multi-agent framework developed by Jomi F. HÃ¼bner and Rafael H. Bordini, wich we didn’t use due to conflicts with our requirements. Instead we based our work on some of their theoretical concepts and ideas.

We tried a lot of different types of frameworks like TerraME, FLAME, GOAL or MASON to create an usable system for our simulation, but without success, so that we build up our framework from scratch.

From another point of view, we had compared the main popular programming language indices Tiobe, RedMonk and PopularitY in 2015 / 2016 and we found out, that agent-programming languages are not listed on any index, only logical programming (Prolog) is found on Tiobe. Our goal for this system is to create a practically usable and well documented framework which can also be used by non-software-developers and included in already existing projects. We try to explain the ideas, concepts and technical background in a clean and understandable way to get a better approval of agent-programming and modelling.

All content of the website is defined under the Creative Commons License (CC BY-SA 4.0)

item.title: AgentSpeak(L++) Language Features
item.description:
We present here a short overview of language examples of our AgentSpeak(L++) syntax. You can found the full EBNF description of the language syntax on the project documentation page. The Railroad / Syntax diagrams of the AgentSpeak(L++) language:

  • Agent Railroad / Syntax Diagram
  • PlanBundle Railroad / Syntax Diagram

Lambda Expression

The language does not support a looping directly, but we are using lambda expression which care based on the theoretical structure of a lambda calculus. In a short word we use a defintion like a for each call, so each element in a variable can be looped.

The example creates a list of the number [1,20) and we are looping over the elements, first in sequential order and call the print action for each element and in the second call we are summarize each value to the variable R. R is in this case the returning variable

L = collection/list/range(1, 20);
(L) -> Y : generic/print(Y);
(L) -> Y | R : R = Y+1;

Explicit Repair-Action

In generell supports the implementation repair planning with the default behaviour -!. In this additional structure we support also repair action chains.

The example shows the execution of three actions actionA, actionB, actionC. The system execute the actionA first, if the action fails, actionB will be executed, if this also fails actionC will be executed. If actionC fails also, the whole plan fails.


actionA << actionB << actionC;

If you don’t want, that a plan is failing, if an action fails you can put at the end of this chain a true value. This models the behaviour anything can go wrong, but the agent ignore the error(s).

actionA << true;

Multi-Plan and Rule Definition

In general Prolog uses only logical rules, AgentSpeak(L) and AgentSpeak(L++) use rules and also adds a plan structure. Within a Prolog structure the ordering of rules and plans are neccessary of the execution semantic (see in Learn Prolog Now!).

But in the AgentSpeak(L++) the ordering of rules and plans are not relevant for the execution semantic. On this case within the source code plan and rule structures are grouped.

This example shows the Ackermann function. The first line defines the rule name (literal) similar to Prolog. Each rule will be added by the :- rule-sign under the literal. In classical Prolog the rule-literal must be for each different rule and Prolog executes the rules in sequential order. In our case we change this behaviour, so that each rule, which can be executed, will be executed. So we put a condition first to the rule, so this condition will deny or allow the execution. After that the rule-body will be added. For calling a rule from a plan or a rule, you need to put a $-sign in front of the rule-name.

ackermann(N, M, R)
    :- N == 0; M > 0; R = M+1
    :- M == 0; N > 0; TN = N-1; $ackermann(TN, 1, RA); R = RA
    :- N > 0; M > 0; TN = N-1; TM = M-1; $ackermann(N, TM, RI); $ackermann(TN, RI, RO); R = RO

The second example shows the structure for plans. For plans it is similar to the rule structure, but the <- plan-sign is used and a condition of the plan execution can be added. Here exist three plans, the first will be executed, iif there is a belief hello with a string value, the second plan will be executed, iif there exists a belief hello with a numeric value which is greater than $1000$ and the third plan will be run every time (default plan).

+!main



: >>( hallo(X), generic/type/isstring(X) ) <-
        generic/print("---", "first plan", "---", "unification variables", X)

: >>( hallo(X), generic/type/isnumeric(X) && X > 1000 )  <-
    generic/print("---", "second plan", "---", "unification variables", X)

<- generic/print("---", "third (default) plan", "---").

Multi Assignments

The multi-assignment allowed to extract elements from a list into different variables. It is similar to the head-tail-notation of Prolog but here we can create complex structures.

The examples creates a list if number within in the range [1,20) and 1 will be put into the variable A, 2 in B, 3 in C, 4 will be ignore, 5 in D, 6 in E, 7 in F and the list [8,20) in G

L = collection/list/range(1, 20);
[A|B|C|_|D|E|F|G] = L;

Parallelism & Thread-Safe Variables

The main sign for parallelism ist the at-sign (@) character. If the @ is put in front of an action or variable the action will be executioned in parallel and the variable will be thread-safe. Not each action supports a parallel execution

item.title: Basic Knowledge: Actions
item.description:
This text gives you an overview over the main build-in actions in LightJason/AgentSpeak(L++).

All actions are organised within the action.buildin package. Each packages defines a semantic structure of the actions. For an example on how to make use of actions have a look at our testing agent which uses many built-in actions provided by AgentSpeak(L++).

collection

collection/size
returns the size of the collection.

collection/list

collection/list/range
creates a list with a integer ranged list.
Description
Creates a list of integer values within the range $ [\text{argument 1}, \text{argument 2}) $ 
L=collection/list/create(0,10);
collection/list/symmetricdifference
creates the symmetric difference between lists (difference of union and intersection).
Description
Creates the symmetric difference of all arguments, so all arguments are collections and the action will return a list with the symmetric difference $ (\mathbb{X} \setminus \mathbb{Y}) \cup (\mathbb{B} \setminus \mathbb{A}) $ 
D=collection/list/symmetricdifference([1,2,[3,4]],[7,8,9,4],[[1,2],[3]]);
See
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetric_difference
collection/list/get
returns an element of the list by the index.
Description
The first argument is a list and the second an index, so the action returns the element 
V=collection/list/get(L,2);
collection/list/flatconcat
returns a flat concated list of any term data.
Description
The arguments of this action are nested lists and the action transfer all nested structures to a straight list 
F=collection/list/flatconcat([1,2,[3,4]],[[1,2],[7,8]]);
collection/list/zip
creates a list of tuples with elements of two lists.
Description
Creates list of tupels of both list arguments $ \mathbb{X} $ and $ \mathbb{Y} $ and returns a list of $ \langle x_i, y_i \rangle $ 
T=collection/list/zip([1,,3,5,7],[2,4,6,8]);
collection/list/intersect
creates the intersection between lists.
Description
All arguments are lists and the action returns the intersection $ \cap M_i \forall i \in \mathbb{N} $ 
I=collection/list/intersect([1,2,[3,4]],[3,4,[8,9]],[1,2,3,5]);
collection/list/create
creates a list.
Description
Creates a list of the arguments, so each argument of the action is put to the list, is the argument empty an empty-list object will be returned 
L=collection/list/create("a",1,"b",2);
collection/list/isempty
checks a list if empty.
Description
Concats all list arguments (and removes the nested structures) and returns a boolean of the empty check 
E=collection/list/isempty([]);
collection/list/union
creates the union between lists (not unique).
Description
Creates the union of all arguemnts with removing nested structures $ \cup X_i \forall i \in \mathbb{N} $ 
U=collection/list/union(L,[1,2],[3,4,[5,6]];
collection/list/set
adds an element to the list.
Description
Sets an element within the list by index, the first argument is the list object, the second the index value and third the new value of the element 
collection/list/set(L,2,"astringvalue");
collection/list/reverse
reverses a list.
Description
All arguments of the action are lists and the action will remove nested structures and reverse all elements in a single list 
R=collection/list/reverse(L,[1,2],[3,4,[7,8]]);
collection/list/complement
creates the complement between lists.
Description
The action uses two input arguments $ \mathbb{A} $ and $ \mathbb{B} $ and returns a list of all elements which contains $ \mathbb{A} \setminus \mathbb{B} $ 
L=collection/list/complement([1,2,3],[3,4,5]);
collection/list/unique
returns an unique list of the list.
Description
All arguments are collections and the action removes nested structures and returns a list with unique elements 
U=collection/list/unique(L);
collection/list/sublist
returns a sublist within the index range.
Description
Creates a sublist of an existing list by an index range, first argument is the list object, second the lower-bound, third the upper-bound within the range $ [ \text{lower-bound}, \text{upper-bound} ) $ 
LS=collection/list/get(L,2,5);
collection/list/remove
returns an element of the list by the index.
Description
Removes an element by the list index, the first argument is the list object, the second argument is the index 
collection/list/remove(L,3);

collection/map

collection/map/remove
removes an element of the map
collection/map/create
creates a hashmap
collection/map/values
returns all values of the map
collection/map/put
adds an element to the map
collection/map/get
returns an element of the map by its key value
collection/map/keys
returns all key values of the map
collection/map/putifabsent
adds an element to the map iif not exists

collection/multimap

collection/multimap/asmap
returns the multimap as map
collection/multimap/get
get a element-list of the multimap by key
collection/multimap/create
creates a multi-hashmap

collection/tuple

collection/tuple/flat
unflats the tuple into variables
collection/tuple/create
creates a tuple of two elements

crypto

crypto/encrypt
encrypting algorithm
crypto/createkey
creates an encrypting / decrypting key pair
crypto/decrypt
dencrypting algorithm
crypto/hash
hash algorithm
See
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/technotes/guides/security/StandardNames.html#MessageDigest
https://github.com/google/guava/wiki/HashingExplained

generic

generic/throw
action for throwing a runtime execption
generic/print
action for sum of elements

generic/agent

generic/agent/planlist
action to get plan-information as a map with string with literal of plan-literal as tupel of successful and failed plans
generic/agent/belieflist
returns a list of all belief literals
generic/agent/sleep
sets the agent to the sleep state for an infinity or fixed time
generic/agent/createliteral
creates a literal by the input data
generic/agent/clearbeliefbase
clears all elements from the beliefbase

generic/datetime

generic/datetime/cycletime
action to get time in nanoseconds to the last cycle call
generic/datetime/time
action for getting the current time
generic/datetime/date
action for getting the current date
generic/datetime/datetime
action to create a date-time structure

generic/storage

generic/storage/remove
removes an element by name from the agent-storage
generic/storage/clear
removes all elements of the storage which are not forbidden
generic/storage/add
adds or overwrites an element in the agent-storage
generic/storage/exists
check if an element exists within the agent-storage

generic/string

generic/string/lower
action to create a lower-case string
generic/string/contains
action to check string for a substring
generic/string/startswith
action to check string for starts-with
generic/string/replace
action to replace any occurence within a string
generic/string/reverse
action to reverse a string
generic/string/endswith
action to check string for starts-with
generic/string/upper
action to create an upper-case string
generic/string/base64encode
action to encodes a string with Base64
See
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Base64
generic/string/base64decode
action to encodes a string with Base64
See
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Base64
generic/string/concat
action to concat strings
generic/string/size
action to get the string length
generic/string/random
action to create a random string

generic/type

generic/type/parseint
action for parsing an integer from string
generic/type/isnumeric
action to check if a type is a number
generic/type/tostring
action to convert any data to its string representation
generic/type/is
action to check if a type is a class
generic/type/toint
action to cast a vale to an integral value
generic/type/isstring
action to check if a type is a string
generic/type/parsefloat
action for parsing a float from string
generic/type/tofloat
action to cast a vale to an floating-point value
generic/type/parseliteral
action for parsing a literal from string
generic/type/to
action to cast any java object type

math

math/tanh
action for tangens hyperbolic value $ tanh( x_i ) $
math/cos
action for cosinus value $ cos( x_i ) $
math/maxindex
action for index of maximum
math/atan
action for tangens value $ tan( x_i ) $
math/stirling
action for calculating stirling number $ S(n,k) $
math/abs
action for absolute value $ \lvert x_i \rvert $
math/log10
action for logarithm (base 10) value $ log_{10} x_i $
math/acos
action for arc cosinus value $ cos( x_i ) $
math/degrees
action for converting value to radians value
math/average
action for average $ \frac{1}{i} \sum_{i} x_i $
math/minindex
action for index of minimum
math/binomial
action for calculating binomial coefficient $ \binom{n}{k} $
math/radians
action for radiant value
math/exp
action for exponential value $ e^{x_i} $
math/floor
action for floor value $ \lfloor x_i \rfloor $
math/nextprime
action for create the next prime number
math/min
action for minimum $ min( x_0, x_1, \ldots, x_i ) $
math/isprime
action for checking for a prime number
math/sqrt
action for sqrt value $ \sqrt{ x_i } $
math/factorial
action for calculating factorial $ ! x_i $
math/log
action for logarithm value $ log( x_i ) $
math/ceil
action for ceil value $ \lceil x_i \rceil $
math/round
action for rounded value
math/asin
action for arc sinus value $ sin( x_i ) $
math/cosh
action for cosinus hyperbolic value $ cosh( x_i ) $
math/signum
action for signum value
math/sin
action for sinus value $ sin( x_i ) $
math/hypot
action for calculating $ \sqrt{ x^2 + y^2 } $
math/tan
action for tangens value $ tan( x_i ) $
math/max
action for maximum $ max( x_0, x_1, \ldots, x_i ) $
math/primefactors
action for creating prime factors
math/sum
action for sum of elements $ \sum_{i} x_i $
math/sinh
action for sinus hyperbolic value $ sinh( x_i ) $

math/blas

math/blas/size
returns the elements within the BLAS structure
math/blas/multiply
defines matrix- / vector-products
math/blas/elementwise
elementweise vector / matrix operation

math/blas/matrix

math/blas/matrix/assign
assigns a value or matrix to all elements
math/blas/matrix/twonorm
returns the two-norm of a matrix
math/blas/matrix/frobeniusnorm
returns the frobenius-norm of a matrix
math/blas/matrix/set
set a single element of a matrix
math/blas/matrix/column
returns a single column of a matrix
math/blas/matrix/determinant
returns the determinant of a matrix
math/blas/matrix/onenorm
returns the one-norm of a matrix
math/blas/matrix/get
returns a single element of a matrix
math/blas/matrix/nonzero
returns the number of non-zero cells
math/blas/matrix/create
creates a dense- or sparse-matrix
math/blas/matrix/copy
returns a copy of the matrix
math/blas/matrix/singularvalue
creates the singular value decomposition of a matrix
math/blas/matrix/rownumber
returns the row number of a matrix
math/blas/matrix/infinitynorm
returns the infinitiy-norm of a matrix
math/blas/matrix/power
returns the matrix power
math/blas/matrix/eigenvalue
creates the eigenvalues of a matrix
math/blas/matrix/rank
rank of the matrix
math/blas/matrix/trace
creates the trace of the matrix
math/blas/matrix/submatrix
returns a submatrix
math/blas/matrix/invert
inverts the matrix
math/blas/matrix/columnnumber
returns the column number of a matrix
math/blas/matrix/sum
returns sum of a matrix
math/blas/matrix/transpose
transpose the matrix
math/blas/matrix/condition
returns the condition of a matrix
math/blas/matrix/parse
creates a dense- or sparse-matrix from a string semicolon splits the rows, spaces / comma splits the columns
math/blas/matrix/solve
solver of matrix-equation $ A \cdot X = B $
math/blas/matrix/row
returns a single row of a matrix

math/blas/vector

math/blas/vector/sum
returns sum of a vector
math/blas/vector/copy
returns a copy of the matrix
math/blas/vector/tolist
converts a vector to a list
math/blas/vector/create
creates a dense- or sparse-vector
math/blas/vector/assign
assigns a value or matrix to all elements
math/blas/vector/set
set a single element of a matrix
math/blas/vector/nonzero
returns the number of non-zero cells
math/blas/vector/dotproduct
returns sum of a vector
math/blas/vector/fromlist
creates a dense- or sparse-vector from a list
math/blas/vector/parse
creates a dense- or sparse-vector from as string seperator is comma, semicolon or space
math/blas/vector/get
returns a single element of a vector

math/interpolate

math/interpolate/interpolate
action to create interpolated values
math/interpolate/create
action to create a spline interpolation

math/linearprogram

math/linearprogram/solve
solves the linear program
math/linearprogram/create
action to create a linear program with an objective functions $ \left( \sum_{i=1} c_i \cdot x_i \right) + d $
math/linearprogram/equationconstraint
add a linear value constraint to the LP with the definition $ \left( \sum_{i=1} c_i \cdot x_i \right) + c_{const} = \left( \sum_{i=1} r_i \cdot x_i \right) + r_{const} $ , $ \left( \sum_{i=1} c_i \cdot x_i \right) + c_{const} \geq \left( \sum_{i=1} r_i \cdot x_i \right) + r_{const} $ $ \left( \sum_{i=1} c_i \cdot x_i \right) + c_{const} \leq \left( \sum_{i=1} r_i \cdot x_i \right) + r_{const} $
math/linearprogram/valueconstraint
add a linear value constraint to the LP with the definition $ \sum_{i=1} c_i \cdot x_i = v $ , $ \sum_{i=1} c_i \cdot x_i \geq v $ $ \sum_{i=1} c_i \cdot x_i \leq v $

math/shape

math/shape/incircle
action check if a point is within a circle
math/shape/intriangle
action check if a point is within a triangle
See
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barycentric_coordinate_system
http://jsfiddle.net/dog_funtom/H7D7g/
math/shape/inrectangle
action check if a point within a rectangle

math/statistic

math/statistic/exponentialproportionateselection
action to define a fitness-proportinate-selection mechanism
See
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boltzmann_distribution
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Log-linear_model
math/statistic/getstatisticvalue
action to return a statistic value
math/statistic/createdistribution
creates a distribution object
math/statistic/randomsimple
create a (set) of simple random values
math/statistic/linearproportionateselection
action to define a exponential fitness-proportinate-selection mechanism
See
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_proportionate_selection
math/statistic/randomsample
create a (set) of random values
math/statistic/createstatistic
action to create a summary statistic
math/statistic/addstatisticvalue
action to push a value to the statistic object
math/statistic/clearstatistic
action to clears the statistic

rest

rest/jsonlist
action for calling a restful service with a json object list
rest/xmlobject
action to call a restful service with xml data
rest/jsonobject
action for calling a restful service with a json object
